intro: Acyntha abyssinica var. sublaevigata, commonly known as the Abyssinian acynthus, is a flowering plant native to Ethiopia. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and clusters of blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its small, tubular flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological role in its native habitat. The variety sublaevigata is distinguished by its relatively smooth leaf surfaces compared to other varieties of the species.
